node.title: The Word of the Year is a perfect illustration of a uniquely Australian predicament
node.alt: Vials of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccines of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna.
node.description: The Word of the Year,Â decided by the ANU's Australian National Dictionary Centre, illustrates the unique predicament the nation found itself in as it worked to vaccinate the population against COVID-19.
node.content:
["The Australian National University has announced its word of the year \u2014\u00a0and unsurprisingly, it was inspired by the pandemic.", "Strollout \u2014 a word that appeared in the first half of the year when critics of the federal government's vaccine rollout started to point to perceived delays \u2014 has been crowned 2021's newest linguistic icon.", "Like last year's choice, 'iso', the new word reveals how\u00a0profoundly the COVID-19 virus has shaped our culture.", "But while 'iso' \u2014\u00a0referring to the situation most of us found ourselves in for months at a time to evade COVID-19 infection \u2014\u00a0was widely-used, this year's word\u00a0may not be as well known.", "Nevertheless, it's\u00a0one that comes with a bit of a sting.", "Decided by the\u00a0Australian National Dictionary Centre, which is based at the ANU, director\u00a0Amanda Laugesen said while other words had been in greater circulation, this particular word was uniquely Australian in origin.", "\"For many Australians, the pace of the [vaccine] rollout was considered too slow,\" she said.", "The Prime Minister early on insisted Australia's vaccine rollout was \"not a race\", but many disagreed, arguing the pace needed to pick up to save lives and get society back to normality as quickly as possible.", "In May, Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)\u00a0Secretary Sally McManus, picked up on those frustrations.\u00a0", "\"We don\u2019t have a vaccine rollout, we have a vaccine strollout,\" she wrote on Twitter.", "\"Aged and disability care workers were all meant to be vaccinated by now. They are not. It\u2019s less than three weeks until winter \u2014\u00a0where is the urgency?\"", "Upon hearing of strollout's accolades today, Ms McManus gave all the credit to ACTU's Assistant Secretary Liam O'Brien \u2014 again, via Twitter.", "\"'Strollout'\u00a0has been named the word of the year. It was actually said by [Mr O'Brien] in an internal ACTU meeting when we were discussing our frustration at the lack of urgency from the Morrison Govt to vaccinate aged care,\" she said.", "
Strollout's history and international appeal
", "'Strollout' alludes to the debate that developed\u00a0around whether Scott Morrison had done enough to secure the millions of doses of Pfizer that would later be in such huge demand.", "But while the word was being bandied about on Twitter, Mr Morrison defended\u00a0the pace of the vaccine rollout during Question Time, saying decisions about supply were being made\u00a0based on health advice.", "", "
Millions of Australians have rolled up their sleeves for a COVID-19 vaccine \u2014 but was it a strollout?(ABC News: Tim Swanston)
", "\"The reference to 'not a race' was first said by the Secretary of the Department of Health, Professor Brendan Murphy,\" Mr Morrison said in early June.", "\"And I affirmed his remarks of the Secretary of Health \u2026\u00a0because all the way through this pandemic, one of the key factors that both our government and the governments around the country and the governments of other countries is that we have always been mindful of the expert advice informing the decisions that we have taken.\"", "But 'strollout'\u00a0caught on nonetheless.", "By July, it\u00a0had gone global \u2014 The Washington Post employed it while\u00a0asking how only six per cent of Australians could be vaccinated when other nations were so far ahead, under a headline reading\u00a0\"Australia\u2019s vaccine 'stroll-out'\u00a0shows the dangers of COVID complacency\".", "The word was also evoked as decisions were made to send more doses to those communities most adversely affected by COVID-19, notably Sydney.", "Dr\u00a0Laugesen said the word of the year was \"yet\u00a0another example of how a truly Australian expression can make waves globally\".", "\"As the Delta strain of COVID-19 spread around Australia, the urgency of vaccinating the population became clear, with words like vaccination hubs, vaccine hesitancy, vaccine passports, vaccine rollout, and double-vaxxed gaining prominence,\" Dr\u00a0Laugesen said.", "
Pandemic a busy time for words
", "", "
Scott Morrison once insisted that the vaccine rollout was \"not a race\", but many disagreed.(AAP: David Caird)
", "'Strollout' was not the only word to burst into being during the pandemic.", "In fact, it has been a very fruitful time for those who study this\u00a0sort\u00a0of thing.", "\"I think the really interesting thing about COVID is that it's just been so productive in terms of its own particular lexicon,\" Dr Laugesen told ABC\u00a0Radio Canberra.", "On the shortlist were other notable words that became common parlance over the year, including 'AUKUS' and 'net zero', both showing the centre is not shy of bringing up controversial subjects.", "Dr\u00a0Laugesen said 'double-vaxxed' had been a strong contender for the top spot, partly because it had been used much more in Australia than in other countries, with the possible exception of Canada.", "But ultimately, the word chosen evokes an issue that could remain central in\u00a0the national conversation as the country prepares to go to the polls."]
